pink primrose: Grows low to the ground, forming a rosette of leaves at the base
elongated leaves with smooth or slightly serrated edges
hard-leaved pocket orchid: orchid-specific flower shape with bilateral symmetry and a prominent lip (labellum)
**Orchid Structure**: Presence of a distinct orchid structure including three sepals and three petals, where one of the petals is often a specialized lip (labellum).
**Petal Arrangement**: Regular flowers often have radial symmetry (actinomorphic) as opposed to the bilateral symmetry of orchids.
Presence of a prominent lip or labellum with intricate patterns
canterbury bells: leaves that are lance-shaped or ovate and can be slightly hairy
leaves that are lance-shaped and toothed
Leaves that are lance-shaped and toothed
english marigold: six petal-like tepals surrounding the corona
tiger lily: Spotted or speckled patterns on the petals
bird of paradise: bird-like appearance of the flower structure
Stiff, pointed flowers resembling a bird's beak
The flower's structure forming a fan-like shape
Stiff, pointed flower structures resembling a bird in flight
monkshood: Absence of tendrils (used for climbing, common in sweet peas)
Palmate leaves with deeply cut lobes
globe thistle: Spikey bracts surrounding the flower head
snapdragon: Leaves are typically lance-shaped, arranged alternately or oppositely
colt's foot: **Flower Petals**: Coltsfoot has narrow, ray-like petals that can give a shaggy appearance, while oxeye daisy has broader, white ray petals arranged around a yellow central disc.
flower shape: daisy-like blooms (colt's foot) vs. four-petaled blooms (corn poppy)
Flower head: Colt's foot flower heads are smaller and often appear before the leaves, while dandelions have larger, more conspicuous flower heads that appear with or after the leaves.
**Flowers**: Colt's foot produces small, bright yellow, dandelion-like flowers; silverbush typically has white to pale pink flowers with a darker center.
king protea: Large, central flower head with a spiky appearance
spiky or pointed bracts surrounding the central dome
overall flower structure resembling a giant blossom rather than a flat, circular disk
spear thistle: Thistle heads: Spear thistle has spiny, bulbous flower heads.
Seed Pods: Spear thistle produces fluffy, wind-dispersed seeds in a spiny receptacle, while thorn apple produces large, spiky, green seed pods that split open to release seeds.
yellow iris: Irregular arrangement of petals, giving an asymmetrical look
Flowers have a delicate, ruffled appearance
Petals are typically narrower and different in shape.
The foliage is long and strap-like.
globe-flower: Bloom shape is more rounded and compact
balloon flower: Broad, ovate leaves with serrated edges
giant white arum lily: Smaller, glossy, heart-shaped spathes that can be red, pink, green, or white
Multiple, funnel-shaped flowers arranged in a cluster
Typically blue, purple, pink, or white flowers
Oval or lance-shaped leaves with a more matte texture
pincushion flower: Generally more intricate and detailed in structure
grape hyacinth: Clustered tightly along a single central stalk
corn poppy: Oval-shaped petals with a slightly crinkled texture
prince of wales feathers: Lack of silver or grayish tone typically found in silverbush foliage
Grows in a dense, bushy form
stemless gentian: typically found in alpine or subalpine regions
Typically found in alpine and subalpine regions
lack of climbing or vining characteristics
Grows in alpine and rocky environments
artichoke: Large, central flower bud that resembles a pinecone
Spiny or prickly tips on the outer bracts
usually found in clustered groupings before blooming
sweet william: More rounded petal edges compared to carnations
love in the mist: Delicate, feathery foliage surrounding the flower
bracts that form a delicate "mist" around the flower
mexican aster: Daisy-like flowers with multiple petals radiating from the center
Daisy-like flower structure with a central disk
ruby-lipped cattleya: Petals that are typically wider and more elaborate
Pseudobulbs at the base of the plant
cape flower: typically more delicate and ornate overall appearance
Petals with a more delicate and elongated shape
great masterwort: Clusters of flowers forming an umbrella-like structure (umbel)
siam tulip: typically found with a basal rosette of wide leaves
lenten rose: Evergreen foliage that persists through winter
barbeton daisy: Flowers resembling those of daisies or sunflowers

Single row of petals radiating from the center
More uniform and symmetrical flower shape
daffodil: Trumpet-shaped central corona (the "trumpet" of the daffodil)
Trumpet-shaped central corona (cup or trumpet part of the flower)
bolero deep blue: Rosette formation with tightly packed petals
Presence of multiple layers of petals
marigold: Bushy, round shape of the flower head
Plant's height and overall bushy appearance
buttercup: Typically smaller and simpler flower structure
oxeye daisy: Leaves are simple and not as deeply lobed as those of gazania
petals are long and narrow, arranged in a flat, radial fashion
common dandelion: Absence of white ray petals around the flower head
Absence of long, slender petals typical of daisies
Seed heads that form fluffy, white spheres (pappus)
petunia: usually white or pinkish in color
wild pansy: Presence of a darker central area or lines radiating from the center
Five-petaled flowers with a distinctive "face" pattern
Ovate to oblong leaves with pointed tips
Rounded or oblong petals with a slight overlap
sunflower: typically found in terrestrial environments, not aquatic
pelargonium: typically distinct strong scent from the leaves when crushed
leaf shape (pelargonium leaves are typically rounded or kidney-shaped with scalloped edges, while hibiscus leaves are often more elongated and have serrated edges)
bishop of llandaff: Part of the dahlia family, typically displaying more pointed petals
gaura: Tendency to sway in the breeze due to the slim stems
orange dahlia: Leaf shape: Dahlia leaves are generally larger and more compound with serrated edges, while gazania leaves are often narrow and sometimes have a silver-grey underside.
leaves that are pinnate with serrated edges
pink-yellow dahlia: Leaf structure: Dahlia leaves are generally larger, broader, and toothed, while Gazania leaves are narrower and smoother.
Leaves that are more oval-shaped and less lobed
Leaf shape: Dahlia leaves are usually broader and more oval, whereas blanket flowers have narrower and more lance-shaped leaves.
japanese anemone: Leaves with toothed edges and lobes
black-eyed susan: Typically a daisy-like appearance with a prominent dark center
silverbush: Flowers often have a delicate, papery texture
californian poppy: Larger, white or creamy yellow petals
Flowers close at night or in cloudy weather
osteospermum: Daisy-like appearance with a central disk and radiating petals
Petals typically radiate out evenly from flower center
spring crocus: Absence of a trumpet-shaped corona at the center
Grass-like leaves with a central white stripe
Thin, grass-like leaves with a central white stripe
windflower: Leaves that are finely divided or lobed
tree poppy: White petals (tree poppies typically have white petals)
Generally, a more delicate, papery petal appearance
gazania: Leaves that are typically grayish-green and lance-shaped
Narrow, linear leaves that are often silver-gray or green
water lily: typically seen blooming on a water surface
thorn apple: Large, trumpet-shaped white or purple flowers
morning glory: Five-pointed star pattern in the center of the flower
passion flower: presence of a central corona (fringe-like structure)
lotus lotus: Numerous petals (often in shades of white or pink)

toad lily: Petals arranged in a symmetrical, star-like formation

Leaves arranged in a whorled or alternate pattern
anthurium: Typically seen growing in terrestrial environments, not aquatic
frangipani: Broad, elliptic leaves with a smooth or slightly undulated edge
clematis: Large, showy petals often with a broad, open shape
hibiscus: leaves that are usually lobed or toothed
The arrangement of leaves around the flower
magnolia: Large, solitary flowers (often with many petals)
a smooth, shiny appearance of leaves
Bloom orientation (magnolias generally have upright flowers; daffodils' flowers nod or face slightly downward)

clusters of flowers rather than single (for watercress)

Leaves that are generally smooth-edged and somewhat glossy

Arrow-shaped leaves often with a leathery texture
mallow: Round or heart-shaped leaves with a crinkled texture
Palmately lobed leaves (like those of a maple tree)

blackberry lily: Small, black seed clusters resembling blackberries
